content:
Let EEE be a Boolean topos satisfying the internal axiom of choice.
This is a question about doing set theory internal to EEE. Not "EEE as model of structural set theory" but closer to "models of set theory in EEE".
Actually the set theory I am interested in here is more material than structural, as I am interested in subsets of AAA modelled as predicates A→ΩA\to\OmegaA→Ω, so we have extensionality and so on.
Let AAA be an object in EEE.

There should, I think, be an internal category structure in EEE where ΩA\Omega^AΩA is the object of objects. The arrows in this category are "functions between subsets of AAA". I am not talking about functions that respect the subset inclusion into A (which are unique if they exist) - the functions in this category can be arbitrary.
I have three different ideas for exactly what the object of arrows should be, which I'll discuss later.

The basic question is: Treating ΩA\Omega^AΩA as the objects of the "category of subsets of A", what assumptions can we impose on AAA so that the subcategory of "small subsets of AAA" (for a suitable definition of "small") has the good properties we want of a category of sets? For example, finite products, finite coproducts, exponentials, limits and colimits indexed by a map B→ΩAB\to \Omega^AB→ΩA for a "small" object BBB, and so on.

Even without "smallness" assumptions, I would expect that if AAA is infinite in the appropriate sense then ΩA\Omega^AΩA has finite products and coproducts, as A+AA+AA+A and A×AA\times AA×A should admit an embedding into AAA. What definitions of "infinite" work here?

My motivations here are practical.
My question is really about the theorem prover Isabelle/HOL, whose logic is very close to that of a Boolean topos satisfying the internal axiom of choice. I want to develop category theory in Isabelle/HOL.
This analogy is not perfect. The most important distinction I have noticed is that the "subobject classifier" in Isabelle actually gives something strictly weaker: for every predicate ϕ:A→bool\phi : A \to \mathsf{bool}ϕ:A→bool such that ∃x.ϕ(x)\exists x.\phi(x)∃x.ϕ(x), there is a subobject of AAA classified by ϕ\phiϕ; but it is essential that the predicate be true for at least one element. This category has no initial object and every object is equipped with a canonical map from the terminal object. Still, for practical purposes it appears one can get away with the constantly-false predicate on an object every time one appears to need the initial object, and so there is no real harm done. It would be a valuable contribution of the categorical logic community if anyone wants to work out what exactly the internal logic of such a category is and how it relates to topos theory, or prove an equivalence between fragments of logic, as this is actually a real world logic that literally thousands of people use! It's very important!

The fact that this is a "real world problem" (I want to actually prove theorems in this logic) is relevant here because it biases me away from verbose solutions to problems which will become unwieldy later on even if they're more categorically elegant.

In the definition of the morphisms of ΩA\Omega^AΩA, the one could do this with functions as relations on AAA, i.e. if X,Y⊂AX,Y\subset AX,Y⊂A then R⊂A×AR\subset A\times AR⊂A×A is a function from X→YX\to YX→Y if ∀xy.(¬Rxy∨(x∈X∧y∈Y))\forall x y. (\lnot R x y \lor (x\in X\land y \in Y))∀xy.(¬Rxy∨(x∈X∧y∈Y)) and ∀x∈X.∃y∈Y.Rxy\forall x\in X.\exists y\in Y. R x y∀x∈X.∃y∈Y.Rxy. My instinct is that relations instead of functions would get pretty unwieldy in actually proving theorems in this logic (I want to use terms to denote values) and so I want to work with a subset of AAA^AAA. There are two relevant definitions that jump out at me here:

• AAA is assumed to be equipped with a distinguished morphism c:1→Ac : 1\to Ac:1→A. For subsets X,YX,YX,Y of AAA, we define YXY^XYX to be the subset of AAA^AAA consisting of all those fff such that f(x)∈yf(x)\in yf(x)∈y for x∈Xx\in Xx∈X and f(x)=cf(x)=cf(x)=c for x∉Xx\notin Xx∈/X. This is easier in the sense that it avoids quotienting.
  • Take the subset of AAA^AAA with f(x)∈Yf(x)\in Yf(x)∈Y for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X and quotient out this object by the relation f∼f′f\sim f'f∼f′ if f(x)=f′(x)f(x)=f'(x)f(x)=f′(x) for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X.

Perhaps all these definitions are isomorphic when AAA is inhabited, I have not thought through that yet.

In conclusion I propose three basic definitions of the "internal category of subsets of AAA and arbitrary functions between them" and ask, for whichever choice of definition you care to investigate, what do we need to assume about AAA in order to do mathematics?

  • under what assumptions on AAA does this internal category have finite products, equalizers, coproducts, coequalizers and so on?
  • under what assumptions of AAA, and for what definition of "small", does this internal category have small limits of small sets, small colimits of small sets and so on?
  • under what assumptions on AAA, and possibly the topos EEE in general, does this category of AAA-sets admit the construction of free monoids, free groups and other algebraic structures? Can we get an internal category of AAA-monoids which is monadic over the category of subsets of AAA?
Since EEE is Boolean and satisfies choice, via the internal language of EEE, we can turn these questions back into questions about ordinary classical set theory, right?
The question is about the category of all sets that are (isomorphic to) subsets of some fixed set AAA.

Then the answers would be (0) these definitions of the morphisms are equivalent, (1) this category has finite (co)limits as soon as AAA is infinite, (2) the category will be closed under small colimits but not under small limits, (3) again as soon as AAA is infinite (or in general, big enough compared to the size of the algebraic theory)
About 2: the category will not have a product of AAA copies of an object with two elements, by Cantor (2A>A2^A > A2A>A).
Usually the good way to build a "category of sets" in classical mathematics is to fix a universe--let's say AAA--of "classes", and make the objects be subsets of AAA of cardinality smaller than AAA.
Then, good cardinal features of AAA will translate into good features of the resulting category of sets.
Yes, that all makes sense. In that case I will need to formalize a little bit of cardinal arithmetic and/or import some additional libraries.
I was hoping for a little more of a lightweight solution but it is certainly the most robust.
